entries.content: When cold calling, offer the prospect the option to hang up immediately or give you 30 seconds.
entries.notes: Used to lower resistance and give control.

entries.content: On a cold call, if they give you 30 seconds, use it to state your name, company, why you called, and ask a qualifying question.
If the cold call goes well, transition to asking for a brief follow-up call or meeting, stating it only takes a few minutes.
Use a soft anchor statement early in the conversation like 'If by the end of this call, you don't feel this is a fit, that's perfectly okay.'
Focus the initial part of a discovery call on gathering information, not pitching.
When presenting a solution, tie it directly back to the specific pain points or goals the prospect shared earlier.
Instead of just presenting features, explain the benefit or outcome of those features for the prospect.
After explaining a concept or solution element, pause and ask a check-in question like 'Does that make sense?' or 'Any questions on that?'
Handle potential pricing objections by framing the price as an investment or tied to the value/ROI the solution provides.
When nearing the end of a demo or presentation, transition to discussing next steps by asking about their level of interest.
Use trial closes or check-ins throughout the conversation to gauge interest and understanding before a final close.
When facing an objection, first acknowledge and validate the prospect's concern before addressing it.
Turn an objection into a question you can answer or reframe it based on previous agreements.
If a prospect is hesitant about commitment, offer a smaller next step like providing more information or scheduling a follow-up.
Structure your pitch or demo to flow logically, starting with understanding needs, presenting solution, and discussing next steps.
Use silence strategically after asking a question or presenting an idea to give the prospect space to respond.
Confirm mutual understanding of the next steps agreed upon at the end of the call.
